review.title: Performance Evaluation of Statistical Approaches for Text Independent Speaker Recognition Using Source Feature
review.abstract: This paper introduces the performance evaluation of statistical approaches for TextIndependent speaker recognition system using source feature. Linear prediction LP residual is used as a representation of excitation information in speech. The speaker-specific information in the excitation of voiced speech is captured using statistical approaches such as Gaussian Mixture Models GMMs and Hidden Markov Models HMMs. The decrease in the error during training and recognizing speakers during testing phase close to 100 percent accuracy demonstrates that the excitation component of speech contains speaker-specific information and is indeed being effectively captured by continuous Ergodic HMM than GMM. The performance of the speaker recognition system is evaluated on GMM and 2 state ergodic HMM with different mixture components and test speech duration. We demonstrate the speaker recognition studies on TIMIT database for both GMM and Ergodic HMM.

Speaker recognition system performance is evaluated on GMM and 2-state ergotic HMM with different mixing components and test speech duration. We demonstrate the speech recognition studies on the TIMIT database for both GMM and Ergodic HMM.Index terms: Ergodic, LP-Residual, MFCC, Speakers.

sections.text: Speech signals, like all other signals in the real world, are generated by excitation of a system with source. A simple block diagram (representation of the speech production mechanism) is shown in Figure 1. Vibrations of vocal folds driven by air from the lungs during exhalation are the sound source for speech. As shown in Figure 1, glottal excitation forms the source, and the voice tract forms the system. The philosophy of linear prediction is closely related to the basic language production model. Linear Predictive Coding (LPC) analyzes spectral analysis on short segments of speech with an all-pole modelling restriction [14]. Since language can be modelled as an output of a linear, time-varying system stimulated by a source, LPC analysis captures the information of the voice tract system in relation to the coefficients of the resistor filter that senses the voice tract signal.

sections.heading: 2.2 Feature extraction of LP residual signal
sections.text: The MFCC technique uses two types of filters, namely linear filters and logarithmic filters. To capture the phonetically important characteristics of speech, the signal is expressed in the Mel frequency scale, which has a linear frequency response of less than 1000 Hz and a logarithmic response of more than 1000 Hz. Normal speech waveforms can vary from time to time depending on the physical state of the speaker's vocal cords. MFCs are less susceptible to these variations [15].

sections.text: Since it is our interest to capture global characteristics that correspond to the excitation by God, the low frequency components should be emphasized. To meet this requirement, MFCC is best suited as it emphasizes low frequencies and degrades high frequencies.

sections.heading: 3. PARAMETRIC APPROACHES
sections.text: Parametric approaches are model-based approaches. The parameters of the model are estimated using the training feature vectors. It is assumed that the model is suitable to represent the distribution. The most commonly used parametric approaches are GMM and HMM-based approaches.

sections.heading: 4. EXPERIMENTAL EVALUATION
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1 Database Used for the Study
sections.text: In general, loudspeaker recognition refers to both loudspeaker recognition and loudspeaker verification. Loudspeaker identification is the task of identifying a specific loudspeaker from a series of loudspeakers. The result of loudspeaker verification is either to accept or reject the speaker's claim. In this essay, we consider the identification task for the TIMIT Speaker databases. The TIMIT body of language is designed to provide loudspeaker data for acoustic-phonetic knowledge acquisition and for the development and evaluation of automatic loudspeaker recognition systems. TIMIT contains a total of 6300 sets, 10 sets spoken by each of 630 speakers from eight major dialect regions of the United States. We consider 200 speakers from 630 speakers for speaker recognition. A maximum of 30 seconds of speech data is used for training and at least 1 second of data for the test. In all cases, the voice queries were pre-tested by 16 speakers to demonstrate loudspeaker recognition.

sections.heading: 4.2 Experimental Setup
sections.text: The system was implemented in Matlab7 on the Windows XP platform. We used the LP sequence 12 for all experiments. We trained the GMM and HMM models using Gaussian total components such as 4, 8, 16 and 32 for each training, the language duration of 30 seconds is tested using different language durations such as 1 second, 3 seconds and 5 seconds. The same setting was implemented for both GMM and Ergodic HMM.

sections.heading: 5. PERFORMANCE EVALAUATION
sections.text: There is no theoretical way to evaluate the performance of the statistical approaches. To evaluate the loudspeaker recognition system, the experiment is performed with a GMM and a 2-state HMM for different numbers of Gaussian components such as 4, 8, 16 and 32. Here, the model is performed with 30 seconds speech duration, LP sequence of 12 and tested at 1 second, 3 seconds and 5 seconds, as shown in Figures 5, 6 and 7, the ergodic HMM for loudspeaker recognition system has exceeded GMM. Experimental results are shown in Table 1. Percentage detection of 2-state ergodic HMM for different Gaussian components such as 4, 8, 16 and 32 appears to increase evenly. The minimum number of Gaussian components to achieve good detection performance appears to be 16, and thereafter the detection performance is minimal.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSION
sections.text: The performance of the system for different HMM states shows that it can effectively capture the speaker-specific excitation information. The main objective of this paper was to demonstrate that the excitation information present in the linear prediction for loudspeaker detection can be captured more effectively than GMM. We have made no attempt to optimize the parameters of the feature extraction model and also the decision-making phase. Therefore, the performance of loudspeaker detection can be improved by optimizing the various design parameters.
